journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Output feedback finite-time control for a bioreactor system based on a finite-time stable observer

article-meta.aff: 1College of Information and Control Engineering, China University of Petroleum, China

author-notes.corresp: Shihua Li, School of Automation, Southeast University, 2 Si Pai Lou, Xuan Wu District, Nanjing, 210096, China Email: lsh@seu.edu.cn

abstract.p: In this paper, an output feedback finite-time controller based on a finite-time stable observer is developed for a bioreactor system. The observer is proposed to estimate the biomass concentration in finite time. Based on the estimation of the biomass concentration, an output feedback controller is designed to track the reference signal in finite time. A Lyapunov function is constructed to prove that the observer is a finite-time stable observer. The finite-time stability results for cascaded systems are employed to prove that the closed-loop system satisfies the finite-time stability. Thus, the observer and the controller can be designed separately, both with finite-time convergence. Numerical simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the method.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The control of bioreactor systems is interesting and attracts much attention from researchers. It is known that a bioreactor system is difficult to control due to its highly nonlinear dynamics, the non-measurability of key state variables and the uncertainty in the process. Nonlinearities are intrinsic to the process and complicated differential equations are used to describe the system dynamics. The complexity of a bioreactor system usually does not permit classical linear controllers to provide good performance for the closed-loop system (Simeonov, 1994). Thus, advanced control approaches are developed for bioreactor systems.

Most control strategies for bioreactors are based on models of the mechanism. For controller design purposes, linearized models are applied to approximate the nonlinear dynamics of the plant. Linear state-space models with bounded parameter variations are used (Georgieva and Ignatova, 2000; Stoyanov, 2000). In the case of a non-minimum-phase bioreactor system, a two-degree-of-freedom controller (Schauer et al., 2000) has been designed for the tracking problem. Usually, good performance is shown only in a limited region since such approaches are based on linearized models.

Generally speaking, nonlinear models of bioreactors are used directly in controller design. In one case, two first-order nonlinear differential equations are used to describe the biomass and the substrate concentration dynamics respectively. A sliding mode control design (Zlateva, 1997) is developed to track the set point change of the substrate concentration. A time-varying sliding surface is defined using angular information that provides adjustable continuous movement of the sliding surface (Tokat 2009). A type-2 fuzzy logic controller (Galluzzo et al., 2008) is applied to a bioreactor system. To maximize the production rate, optimal static points which depend on model parameters should be calculated at first (Krastanov and Dimitrova, 2003; Zhang et al., 2003). Assuming that the parameters of the model are bounded, a nonlinear continuous control law (Krastanov and Dimitrova, 2003) is constructed to asymptotically stabilize the uncertain system to the set of all optimal static points. A parameter estimation algorithm (Zhang et al., 2003) is developed for the unknown parameters. Then an adaptive extremum-seeking controller is presented to drive the system states to optimal points. For simultaneous control of the biomass and substrate concentrations, a controllability analysis is proposed (Deschênes et al., 2005) and multivariable adaptive control is presented (Tsao and Wu, 1994). Some other works are based on a dimensionless bioreactor system model (Fossas et al., 2001; Fossas et al. 2004; Efe, 2007).

In the other case, the dynamic variable of product concentration is also included to describe the processes. Binary control design is proposed because it has the advantage of robustness against uncertainties and external disturbances (Zlateva, 2000). Two sliding mode control methods (Tham et al., 2003) are studied by using fixed switching gain and adaptive switching gain respectively. Based on these two approaches, a hybrid sliding mode control method is proposed. For non-minimum-phase bioreactor systems with disturbances, output regulation (Wu and Huang, 2003) is investigated. A type-2 fuzzy logic control is proposed for a continuous bioreactor characterized by bifurcations (Galluzzo and Cosenza, 2009). The performance of a bioreactor system is tested by using internal model control (IMC), model predictive control and augmented IMC strategies respectively in the case of multiple-input–multiple-output (MIMO) operation (Saha et al., 1999).

Most of the above control laws demand knowledge of the process variables. However, this is not always available. A major difficulty is the lack of cheap and reliable instrumentation for the online measurement of the main process variables and parameters such as biomass, product concentration and growth rate.

Due to the non-measurability of state variables, an output feedback controller based on an observer has attracted much attention in the last decade. Both the unmeasured disturbances and the states are estimated (Biagiola and Figueroa, 2004a; 2004b). A nonlinear controller (Biagiola and Figueroa, 2004a) based on exact linearization is designed. A nonlinear model predictive controller (Biagiola and Figueroa, 2004b) is introduced. An adaptive extremum-seeking controller based on a reduced-order observer is designed for optimization of the production rate (Marcos et al., 2004). For a uniformly observable MIMO system, Imsland et al. (2003) combine nonlinear model predictive control schemes with high-gain observers to achieve output feedback stabilization. Some control strategies consider the model uncertainties and nonmeasurable state as one new nonmeasurable state variable (Aguilar et al., 2001; González et al., 1998; González et al., 2001). A robust adaptive linearizing feedback control law (González et al., 1998) is proposed based on a numerical observer which is used online to obtain discrete estimates of kinetics terms, yielding production and biomass concentration. An input–output linearizing controller (González et al., 2001) is presented based on a sliding mode observer (SMO). A controller consisting of proportional and double integral feedback is designed based on a reduced-order uncertainty observer and an input–output linearizing control strategy (Aguilar et al., 2001).

Finite-time stability means finite time convergence and Lyapunov stability. Finite-time stable systems might enjoy faster convergence and better disturbance rejection (Bhat and Bernstein, 1998). The convergence in conventional Lyapunov stable systems is at best exponential with infinite setting time. A nonsmooth but continuous finite-time controller (FTC) can make the controlled system reach its targets in a finite time (Hong et al., 2006). Some analysis and synthesis results are presented in Haimo (1986), Bhat and Bernstein (1997, 1998), Hong et al. (2001), Qian and Li (2005), Yu et al. (2005), Hong et al. (2006), Li and Qian (2006), Li and Tian (2007), Moreno and Osorio (2008), Li et al. (2009a, 2009b), Wang et al. (2009), and Xia et al. (2011). Some output feedback finite-time controllers based on finite-time stable observers (Hong et al., 2001; Li and Qian, 2006; Qian and Li, 2005) are presented for different kinds of systems. A finite-time controller (Li et al., 2009b) is designed for a continuous bioreactor by using a nonsingular terminal sliding mode technique. The substrate concentration of the closed-loop system reaches the set point from any initial state in finite time and is then maintained at the desired value. This requires that both the biomass concentration and the substrate concentration are measurable.

In this paper, we consider the finite-time observer design for the biomass concentration and output feedback finite-time control of the substrate concentration. The proposed finite-time observer and output feedback finite-time controller can provide very good tracking precision and better disturbance rejection. Compared with a sliding mode observer, the proposed finite-time observer is continuous. The procedure is divided into three steps. First, a global finite-time controller based on state feedback is designed. Then a global finite-time observer is constructed to estimate the unmeasured state. Finally, an output feedback controller is obtained based on the estimated state.

This paper has two contributions. One is the finite-time observer design. In fact, finite-time convergence of observation is an attractive feature which is very important for bioreactor systems. The dynamic model of the bioreactor is a highly nonlinear system. It cannot be transformed to any one of the systems in Hong et al. (2001), Qian and Li (2005), Li and Qian (2006) or Moreno and Osorio (2008). Therefore the state observers mentioned above cannot be applied here. A specially designed finite-time observer for the bioreactor system is obtained. The other contribution is the application of finite-time stability results of a cascaded system (Li and Tian, 2007). For the stability analysis of a closed-loop system, it is very difficult to construct an appropriate Lyapunov function to prove the finite-time stability. The forward completeness condition is enough to ensure the uniform global finite-time stability of the system here (Li and Tian, 2007). As a result, the construction of the Lyapunov function for the whole closed-loop system is not needed.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The bioreactor mathematical model is presented in Section 2. Section 3 proposes the main result of this paper, where an output feedback finite-time controller is designed based on a novel finite-time observer. Section 4 shows the numeric simulation results. The conclusions are given at the end of this paper.

sec.title: Bioreactor mathematical model
sec.p: The process considered here is a continuous bioreactor which is a tank containing water, substrate and biological cells as shown in Figure 1. The feeding substrate is diluted in the water stream and then continuously introduced into the tank. The culture remains constant by the same rate of inflow and outflow. The concentration at the outlet is equal to that inside the bioreactor. The growth of one population of microorganisms on a single limiting substrate is investigated.

The dynamic behaviour of a bioreactor is obtained by using mass balance. A general dynamic model of a bioreactor is described by the following two nonlinear differential equations (Bastin and Dochain, 1990):

where X is the biomass concentration, S the substrate concentration, D>0 the dilution rate, Sin the influent substrate concentration and k=1/Yd the yield coefficient. We assume that the state X is nonmeasurable and the state S can be measured online. The control input u is the dilution rate and the output y is the substrate concentration, i.e. u=D, y=S.

The nonlinear function α denotes the specific growth rate, which is the key parameter for the description of bioreactor activity. It is a differentiable function of time and can be expressed as follows:

where p is a vector of the kinetic coefficients. The most commonly used model for the specific growth rate α is the Monod model (Bastin and Dochain, 1990), which is solely a function of the substrate concentration:
and kinetic coefficients vector p=(μm,km), where μm is the maximum specific growth rate and km is the saturation coefficient. μm and km are constants.

The yield coefficient Yd is an extremely important parameter since it represents the efficiency of the conversion of substrate into biomass. A linearly increasing yield coefficient can be expressed as follows:
where a′ and b′ are positive constants.

The equilibria of the process are obtained by setting the left-hand side of (1) to zero. We obtain two equilibria (Xe,Se) corresponding to a constant dilution rate D and a constant k. The first equilibrium is Xe=0 and Se=Sin, which is called the washout steady state because the biomass concentration is reduced to zero. The second equilibrium is
which is called the non-washout steady state of the process.
On the basis of expert knowledge and biological requirements, we have:
where Smax, Smin are constants.

sec.title: Output feedback finite-time controller design
sec.p: The proposed output feedback finite-time controller consists of a state feedback finite-time controller and a finite-time observer for estimating the nonmeasurable state. The control objective is that the substrate concentration should track set-point changes in finite time and then be maintained at the desired level, starting from arbitrary initial conditions.

sec.title: Design of the state feedback finite-time controller
sec.p: If we denote the desired substrate concentration as r(t), then we define the substrate concentration error as:
The following differential equation of the error is therefore obtained:
For convenience, let sigγx=sgn(x)|x|γ for γ>0, where sgn(·) is the sign function. For the error system (12), a finite-time controller is designed as:
where c>0 and β∈(0,1) are constants.
Substituting (13) into (12), we have:
The dynamics of system (14) will reach e=0 at a finite time tc. It can be concluded that tc is determined by
Proposition 1. The origin is a globally finite-time stable equilibrium of the error dynamics (12) under the feedback control law (13) with c>0 and β∈(0,1).
Proof. Consider a continuously differentiable Lyapunov function
It is easy to see that Lyapunov function V1 is positive-definite. The derivative of V1 along (14) is
Since β∈(0,1), we have 0<(1+β)/2<1. By virtue of Lemma 1, the origin is a globally finite-time stable equilibrium of (12). Thus the proof is completed.

Note that as the biomass concentration X is nonmeasurable here, the control law (13) cannot be applied directly. In what follows we construct a finite-time stable observer to estimate the nonmeasurable state X.

sec.title: Design and analysis of the finite-time observer
sec.p: Define the observation errors as X~=X^−X, S~=S^−S, where X^ and S^ are the estimates of X and S given by the state observer respectively. The observer can be constructed as follows:

where α1, α2 and k2 are positive gains of the observer, k1 and k3 are positive functions to be determined later, β1, β2∈(0,1) are constants. Since the substrate concentration is assumed to be measurable, here at the initial time we can take S^(0) satisfying S^(0)=S(0).
Using (1) and (18), the dynamic equations of the observation errors are:
Now, we will prove that the observer (18) is a finite-time observer.

Proposition 2. The state observer (18) is a finite-time observer, i.e. the zero solution of the error dynamics (19) is globally finite-time stable, if 0<β2<β1<1, k3=|−kαX~S~−α2S~2|/|S~|1+β1+α3andk1≥k3/kwithα3>0.
Proof. Consider a Lyapunov function
It is easy to see that Lyapunov function V2 is positive-definite. The derivative of V2 along (19b) is
Substituting
into (21) yields:
Since β1∈(0,1), we have 1+β12∈(0,1). By virtue of Lemma 1, the zero solution of the error dynamics (19b) is globally finite-time stable. When S~=0, we obtain the following result from (19):
Consider a Lyapunov function
It is easy to see that Lyapunov function V3 is positive-definite. The derivative of V3 along (24) is
According to k1≥k3k, we have α−D−k1kαk3<−D. From (5), we obtain that S is bounded. Therefore, we have:

where c1=−D<0 and c2=maxk,α{−k2(kαk3)β2β1}<0. Since 0<β2<β1<1, we have β1+β22β1∈(0,1). By virtue of Lemma 1, the zero solution of the error dynamics (19a) is globally finite-time stable. Then the zero solution of the error dynamics (19) is globally finite-time stable, which means that the state observer (18) is a finite-time observer. Thus the proof is completed.

Remark 1. It should be pointed out that the proposed observer structure (18) can be considered as a generalization of observers in the literature (González et al., 2001; Davila et al., 2005). If β1=0 and k2=0, the observer (18) has the form of the observer in González et al. (2001). If α1=0, α2=0, β1=0 and k1=0, the observer (18) has the form of the observer in Davila et al. (2005). Compared with these two observers, the proposed observer is a continuous finite-time observer.

sec.title: Analysis of finite-time stability
sec.p: Theorem 1. For the bioreactor process (1), the output S will track a reference input r(t) in finite time under the following continuous control law:

where
X
^
is defined as in (18a).
Proof. Substituting the control law (28) into (12) yields
Consider subsystems (29) and (24) as a cascaded system:

where f1(e)=−csigβe, g(X~)=−kαX~. It is easy to see that g(0)=0 and f(e,X~), f2(X~) are locally Hölder continuous in e, X~. From Proposition 1 and Proposition 2, we obtain that Assumptions A1 and A2 of Lemma 2 are satisfied, i.e. the two subsystems are UGFTS respectively. Next we will show that the cascaded system (30) and (31) will also satisfy the uniform forward completeness condition.
Consider the finite-time bounded function B(e)=e22, which is obviously a decrescent function. Taking the derivative of B(e) along solutions of (29) yields:

According to (5) and (2), the existence of a constant αmax is ensured such that the inequality kα≤αmax holds. Since the subsystem (31) is UGFTS, X~ is bounded, i.e. X~≤X~max, where X~max=max{X~(t),t≥0}. There are two cases for e. One case is |e|≥1. In this case, we obtain
where K=2αmaxX~max.
The other case is |e|<1. For this case, there exists a constant L=αmaxX~max>0 such that B·(e)≤L. Combining both cases together, we obtain
Let β6(s)=Ks+L. Obviously, the forward completeness condition is satisfied.

By virtue of Lemma 2, the cascaded system (29) and (24) is uniformly globally finite-time stable under the control law (28) and the observer (18). That is, for the bioreactor system (1), the output S will track a reference input r(t) in finite time. Thus, the proof is completed.

Remark 2. Usually, it is difficult to construct an overall Lyapunov function for system (30)–(31) which satisfies the conditions in Lemma 1. Here, the finite-time stability result of the cascaded system is applied to prove the global finite-time stability of the closed-loop system. A forward completeness condition in Lemma 2 is verified to ensure the uniform global finite-time stability of the closed-loop tracking error system. Construction of Lyapunov function for the whole closed-loop system is not needed. Furthermore, the separation principle is satisfied, i.e. the finite-time observer and the finite-time state feedback control law can be designed separately.

sec.title: Numerical simulation
sec.p: In this section, we will verify the effectiveness of the proposed output feedback finite-time controller by numerical simulations for a bioreactor. The parameters involved in the bioreactor model are chosen as in González et al. (2001):

The initial conditions for the concentrations in the bioreactor are: S(0)=0g/l and X(0)=1g/l. Since the substrate concentration S is measurable and there is no prior information about the biomass substrate X, the initial conditions for the finite-time observer are taken as: S^(0)=S(0)=0 and X^(0)=0.
In simulation, the parameters involved in our controller are chosen as c=3.15,0<β=0.6<1. The parameters involved in our observer are chosen as:
The set point is r=1.531g/l.
In order to investigate the performances of our controller and observer, comparisons have been made with two other methods. An SMO is constructed as follows (González et al., 2001):
Based on the SMO, an asymptotically stable controller and a finite-time controller are designed respectively. The asymptotically stable controller can be designed as (González et al., 2001):
The finite-time controller can be designed as (28).

Note that our observer (18) has the same form as (34) if assuming β1=0 and k2=0 in (18). To have a fair comparison, all of the control output signals are limited not to exceed 0.15h−1. We have spent time on regulating the parameters for the other two methods to make the performances of the closed-loop system and the observer as good as possible under this restriction. In simulation, the parameters for the SMO (34) are chosen as α1=3, α2=5, k1=3 and k3=1. The parameter for the controller (35) is chosen as τc=0.4 and the parameters for the controller (28) are chosen as c=3, β=0.8.

Figures 2–4 show the simulation results for a tracking case without disturbance. Figure 2 shows the closed-loop transient behaviors of the substrate concentration S under the three controllers. The responses of the substrate concentration track the set point in all cases. It can be observed that the finite-time controller drives the substrate concentration to the desired point with a faster convergence than that in González et al. (2001). Figure 3 illustrates the performances of the three observers. Since the SMO (34) is discontinuous, its response has small oscillations around the true value all the time. As shown in Figure 3, our method has a smoother estimation for the true state X. Figure 4 represents the behaviours of the dilution rate D. Note that since the estimation of the biomass concentration is directly used in the other two controllers, the dilution rate under the other two controllers also oscillates all the time like the estimation of the biomass concentration in Figure 3. It is observed that our method leads to a smoother control.

caption.p: Process behaviour of the substrate concentration when the set point is changed.
Process behaviour of X and X^ when the set point is changed. (a) Our method; (b) SMO (c) SMO+FTC.
Process behaviour of the dilution rate when the set point is changed. (a) Total; (b) local.

sec.p: For the case of the other process parameters, e.g. the following parameters involved in the bioreactor model,
our control method is still available. Figures 5–7 show the simulation results in this case. It is shown that our method also has a good performance.

caption.p: Process behaviour of the substrate concentration when the set point is changed with μm=0.4, km=0.4, k=27.3, Sin=3.
Process behaviour of X and X^ when the set point is changed with μm=0.4, km=0.4, k=27.3, Sin=3.
Process behaviour of the dilution rate when the set point is changed with μm=0.4, km=0.4, k=27.3, Sin=3.

sec.p: To compare the disturbance rejection ability between the three controllers, a sustained disturbance is introduced on the influent substrate concentration. The sustained disturbance is taken as follows:
where Sin0=35.0g/l, A=5.0g/l and ω=1.0h−1. The simulation results are shown in Figures 8–10.

caption.p: Process behaviour of the substrate concentration in the presence of disturbance.
Process behaviour of the dilution rate in the presence of disturbance.
Process behaviour of X and X^ in the presence of disturbance. (a) Our method (b) SMO (c) SMO+FTC.

sec.p: Figure 8 illustrates the closed-loop responses of the substrate concentration with disturbance. In Figure 8, our method maintains the substrate concentration in a smaller neighbourhood of the reference value. It has an obviously stronger resistance to disturbance. Figure 9 represents the behaviours of the dilution rate D in this case. The dilution rate under our method is smoother compared with the other two methods. Figure 10 shows the observer performances. Comparing the observer performances, we see that our observer has a higher observation precision.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, an output feedback finite-time controller for a bioreactor system has been proposed by combining a finite-time stable observer with a finite-time state feedback controller. The observer has been presented for the estimation of biomass concentration and provides finite-time convergence for the estimation error. The finite-time stability of the observer has been proved by using a finite-time Lyapunov function. The finite-time stability of the closed-loop system has been proved by using the finite-time stability results of the cascaded system. Finally, the validity of the proposed method has been demonstrated by numerical simulations.
